Assumption Checking Wrapper

Source: R/assumptions_wrapper.R
check_test_assumptions.Rd

This file provides a unified interface for checking statistical assumptions across different test types. It eliminates duplicated assumption-checking logic across analysis functions.

Usage

check_test_assumptions(
  test_type = c("t_test", "anova", "regression", "correlation"),
  data = NULL,
  groups = NULL,
  residuals = NULL,
  predictors_data = NULL,
  alpha = 0.05,
  data_structure = "cross_sectional",
  verbose = TRUE
)

Arguments

test_type

Character. One of: "t_test", "anova", "regression", "correlation"

data

Data frame or NULL. Required for independence checks

groups

Character vector or NULL. Group variable for homogeneity tests

residuals

Numeric vector or NULL. Residuals for normality tests

predictors_data

Data frame or NULL. Predictors for VIF/multicollinearity

alpha

Numeric. Significance level (default: 0.05)

data_structure

Character. "cross_sectional" or "longitudinal" (default: "cross_sectional")

verbose

Logical. Show beginner-friendly warnings? (default: TRUE)

Value

S3 object of class c("assumptions_result", "list") with components:

independence

Result from check_independence()

normality

Result from check_normality()

homogeneity

Result from check_homogeneity_of_variance() (if applicable)

multicollinearity

Result from check_vif() (if applicable)

overall_pass

Logical indicating if all assumptions met

test_type

Character string of test type

warnings

Character vector of beginner-friendly warnings

See also

Other infrastructure: .apa7_templates, build_analysis_result()

Examples

# T-test assumptions
data <- data.frame(
  group = rep(c("A", "B"), each = 50),
  value = c(rnorm(50, 10, 2), rnorm(50, 12, 2))
)
model <- lm(value ~ group, data = data)
check_test_assumptions(
  test_type = "t_test",
  data = data,
  groups = "group",
  residuals = residuals(model)
)

#> Test Used: Independence Assessment 
#> Result: PASS ASSUMPTION MET

#> INTERPRETATION:

#>   survey) and autocorrelation testing (r = 0.056).
#> 
#> 
#> RECOMMENDATION:
#>   Each observation represents a unique, independent unit. Standard statistical
#>   procedures (t-tests, ANOVA, linear regression) are appropriate. No special
#>   corrections needed.

#> 
#> PUBLICATION-READY TEXT:
#>   The data were collected using a cross-sectional survey design, ensuring
#>   independence of observations. Independence was confirmed via autocorrelation
#>   testing (r = 0.056).

#> DETAILED EXPLANATION (for learning and context):
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---

#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> 
#>   WHAT IS INDEPENDENCE OF OBSERVATIONS?
#>   
#>   Independence of observations is one of the most important assumptions in
#>   statistics. It means each data point represents a unique individual or unit,
#>   and one participant's response doesn't influence another's response (beyond
#>   random chance).
#>   
#>   Think of it this way: If you know Person A's score, does that tell you
#>   anything about Person B's score beyond what you'd expect by chance? If not,
#>   they're independent.
#>   
#>   YOUR STUDY DESIGN:
#>   
#>   Design type: cross-sectional survey Observations: 100 Autocorrelation: 0.056
#>   (< 0.3 threshold)
#>   
#>   Based on your design and testing, the observations are independent. This is
#>   excellent! You can proceed with standard statistical analyses without special
#>   corrections.
#>   
#>   WHY THIS MATTERS:
#>   
#>   When independence is met: • Standard errors are correctly estimated •
#>   P-values are accurate • Confidence intervals have proper coverage • You can
#>   use all standard statistical tests
#>   
#>   If independence were violated (it's not in your case): • Standard errors
#>   would be TOO SMALL • P-values would be TOO SMALL (inflated Type I error) •
#>   You'd get false positives
#>   
#>   COMMON VIOLATIONS TO WATCH FOR (in future studies):
#>   
#>   • Repeated measures: Same person measured multiple times • Time series:
#>   Today's value depends on yesterday's • Clustered data: Students within
#>   classrooms, customers within stores • Matched pairs: Siblings, couples, or
#>   intentionally paired units • Social networks: Friends influencing friends
#>   
#>   If you had violations, you'd need: • Repeated measures ANOVA (for repeated
#>   data) • Mixed effects models (for clustered/nested data) • Time series
#>   methods (for sequential data) • Paired tests (for matched data)
#> 
#> 
#> ========================================================================
#> INDEPENDENCE CHECKLIST: Questions to Ask About Your Study
#> ========================================================================
#> 
#> Work through these questions to assess independence:
#> 
#> 1. DATA COLLECTION DESIGN:
#>    □ Did each participant contribute only ONE observation?
#>    □ Were participants randomly sampled from the population?
#>    □ Could one participant's response influence another's?
#> 
#> 2. REPEATED MEASURES:
#>    □ Is anyone measured more than once?
#>    □ Are there pre-test and post-test measurements?
#>    □ Do you have multiple items per person?
#>    → If YES to any: Use repeated measures methods
#> 
#> 3. CLUSTERING/NESTING:
#>    □ Are participants grouped (classrooms, stores, teams)?
#>    □ Do participants within groups share experiences?
#>    □ Were participants recruited as groups?
#>    → If YES to any: Use mixed effects models
#> 
#> 4. TIME/SEQUENCE:
#>    □ Are observations ordered in time?
#>    □ Could today's value depend on yesterday's?
#>    □ Is there a trend over time?
#>    → If YES to any: Use time series methods or include time effects
#> 
#> 5. MATCHING/PAIRING:
#>    □ Are observations intentionally paired (couples, siblings)?
#>    □ Did you match participants on characteristics?
#>    □ Are there natural pairs in your data?
#>    → If YES to any: Use paired tests
#> 
#> 6. SOCIAL NETWORK:
#>    □ Do participants know each other?
#>    □ Could social influence affect responses?
#>    □ Did you sample from interconnected groups?
#>    → If YES to any: Use network analysis methods
#> 
#> DECISION RULE:
#> 
#> If you answered YES to ANY question above, your data likely violates independence.
#> You MUST use specialized methods that account for the dependence structure.
#> 
#> When in doubt: Consult a statistician or use mixed effects models (they're robust).
#> ========================================================================
#> 
#> ========================================================================
#> VISUAL DIAGNOSTICS: How to Detect Independence Violations
#> ========================================================================
#> 
#> Independence violations can sometimes be detected visually:
#> 
#> --- AUTOCORRELATION PLOT (For Time Series Data) ---
#> 
#> Create the plot:
#>   # Using residuals from a model
#>   model <- lm(outcome ~ predictors, data = your_data)
#>   res <- residuals(model)
#>   
#>   # Autocorrelation function
#>   acf(res, main = "Autocorrelation of Residuals")
#> 
#> How to interpret:
#>   • Spikes within blue dashed lines = No autocorrelation ✓
#>   • Spikes outside blue lines = Autocorrelation detected
#>   • Lag 1 spike = Adjacent observations correlated
#>   • Pattern of spikes = Systematic dependence
#> 
#> --- RESIDUALS VS ORDER PLOT ---
#> 
#> Create the plot:
#>   model <- lm(outcome ~ predictors, data = your_data)
#>   plot(residuals(model), type = "l",
#>        main = "Residuals Over Time",
#>        ylab = "Residuals")
#>   abline(h = 0, col = "red")
#> 
#> How to interpret:
#>   • Random scatter around zero = Independent ✓
#>   • Patterns or trends = Dependence
#>   • Clustering of similar values = Autocorrelation
#>   • Runs above/below zero = Non-independence
#> 
#> --- CLUSTER/GROUP COMPARISON ---
#> 
#> Create the plot:
#>   boxplot(outcome ~ cluster_id, data = your_data,
#>           main = "Outcome by Cluster")
#> 
#> How to interpret:
#>   • Different median levels across clusters = Clustering effect
#>   • Wide variation between clusters = Non-independence
#>   → Need mixed effects model with random intercepts
#> 
#> --- DURBIN-WATSON TEST (Formal Test) ---
#> 
#> YOUR DURBIN-WATSON STATISTIC: 0.062
#> 
#> Interpretation:
#>   • DW ≈ 2.0: No autocorrelation ✓
#>   • DW < 1.5: Positive autocorrelation (successive values similar)
#>   • DW > 2.5: Negative autocorrelation (successive values alternate)
#> 
#> Your value suggests POSITIVE AUTOCORRELATION - observations are dependent
#> 
#> PRACTICAL ADVICE:
#> 
#>   • If unsure: Assume dependence and use robust methods
#>   • Mixed effects models are rarely wrong (even if independence holds)
#>   • Standard methods with dependence are often wrong
#>   • Better to be conservative than to get false positives
#> ========================================================================
#> 
#>

#> STATISTICAL ASSUMPTION CHECK: Normality
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> 
#> Test Used: Shapiro-Wilk 
#> Result: PASS ASSUMPTION MET 
#> p-value: 0.519 
#> Sample size: 100 
#> 
#> INTERPRETATION:
#>   The normality assumption is MET for data (Shapiro-Wilk W = 0.9881, p = .519,
#>   p > 0.05).
#> 
#> 
#> RECOMMENDATION:
#>   Parametric tests (e.g., t-tests, ANOVA, linear regression) are appropriate.
#>   The data distribution does not significantly deviate from normality.
#> 
#> 
#> PUBLICATION-READY TEXT:
#>   Data normality was assessed using the Shapiro-Wilk test. The data variable
#>   met the normality assumption (W = 0.9881, p = .519).
#> 
#> 
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> DETAILED EXPLANATION (for learning and context):
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> 
#>   The Shapiro-Wilk test evaluates whether a sample comes from a normally
#>   distributed population. The null hypothesis states that the data are normally
#>   distributed. With a p-value of 0.519 (which is greater than our alpha level
#>   of 0.05), we fail to reject the null hypothesis. This means we do not have
#>   sufficient evidence to conclude that the data significantly deviate from a
#>   normal distribution.
#>   
#>   In practical terms: Your data for data appears to follow a bell-shaped
#>   (normal) distribution, which is excellent news. This means you can proceed
#>   with parametric statistical tests that assume normality (such as t-tests,
#>   ANOVA, and linear regression) with confidence. These tests tend to be more
#>   powerful than their non-parametric alternatives when assumptions are met.
#>   
#>   Technical details: The Shapiro-Wilk W statistic ranges from 0 to 1, with
#>   values closer to 1 indicating better fit to normality. Your W value of 0.9881
#>   suggests a good fit. Skewness = -0.239 (values near 0 indicate symmetry), and
#>   excess kurtosis = -0.23 (values near 0 indicate normal tail behavior).
#> 
#> 
#> ========================================================================
#> VISUAL DIAGNOSTICS: How to Check Normality with Plots
#> ========================================================================
#> 
#> Creating diagnostic plots is often more informative than statistical tests alone.
#> Here's how to create and interpret the two most useful plots:
#> 
#> --- Q-Q PLOT (Quantile-Quantile Plot) ---
#> 
#> Create the plot:
#>   qqnorm(your_data, main = "Q-Q Plot: data")
#>   qqline(your_data, col = "red")
#> 
#> How to interpret:
#>   • Points fall ON the red line = Normal distribution ✓
#>   • Points curve ABOVE the line at ends = Heavy tails (outliers)
#>   • Points curve BELOW the line at ends = Light tails (no outliers)
#>   • S-shaped curve = Skewed distribution
#>   • Systematic deviation = Non-normal
#> 
#> What's considered 'good enough':
#>   - Some deviation is normal, especially at the extremes
#>   - Focus on the middle 80% of points
#>   - Minor wiggles are OK; systematic patterns are concerning
#> 
#> --- HISTOGRAM WITH NORMAL CURVE ---
#> 
#> Create the plot:
#>   hist(your_data, 
#>        breaks = 20,
#>        prob = TRUE,
#>        main = "Distribution of data",
#>        xlab = "data",
#>        col = "lightblue")
#>   curve(dnorm(x, mean = mean(your_data), sd = sd(your_data)),
#>         add = TRUE, col = "red", lwd = 2)
#> 
#> How to interpret:
#>   • Bell-shaped curve = Likely normal ✓
#>   • Long tail on right = Positive skew (common in income, prices)
#>   • Long tail on left = Negative skew (common in test scores near max)
#>   • Two peaks = Bimodal (may have two subgroups)
#>   • Flat distribution = Uniform (not normal)
#> 
#> --- COMBINED DIAGNOSTIC CODE ---
#> 
#> Run both plots side-by-side:
#>   par(mfrow = c(1, 2))  # Create 2-panel layout
#>   
#>   # Q-Q Plot
#>   qqnorm(your_data, main = "Q-Q Plot")
#>   qqline(your_data, col = "red")
#>   
#>   # Histogram
#>   hist(your_data, prob = TRUE, main = "Distribution",
#>        col = "lightblue", breaks = 20)
#>   curve(dnorm(x, mean = mean(your_data), sd = sd(your_data)),
#>         add = TRUE, col = "red", lwd = 2)
#>   
#>   par(mfrow = c(1, 1))  # Reset layout
#> 
#> YOUR DATA CHARACTERISTICS:
#>   Sample size:  100
#>   Mean:         0
#>   SD:           1.78
#>   Skewness:     -0.239 (approximately symmetric)
#>   Kurtosis:     -0.23 (normal tails)
#> 
#> PRACTICAL ADVICE:
#>   • With n < 30: Visual inspection is more reliable than statistical tests
#>   • With n > 100: Tests become very sensitive; focus on practical importance
#>   • Mild violations + large sample = Usually OK to proceed with parametric tests
#>   • Severe violations = Use non-parametric tests or transformations
#> ========================================================================
#>

#> ===

#> Test Used: Levene's Test 
#> Result: PASS ASSUMPTION MET 
#> p-value: 0.0737 
#> 
#> INTERPRETATION:
#>   The homogeneity of variance assumption is MET (Levene's test: F(1, 98) =
#>   3.269, p = .074).
#> 
#> 
#> RECOMMENDATION:
#>   The groups have similar variances. Standard t-test or ANOVA procedures are
#>   appropriate. The variance ratio (largest/smallest) is excellent (ratio = 1.57
#>   < 2).
#>

#> PUBLICATION-READY TEXT:
#>   Homogeneity of variance was assessed using Levene's test. The assumption was
#>   met (F(1, 98) = 3.269, p = .074), indicating equal variances across groups.

#> ---
#> 
#>   WHAT IS HOMOGENEITY OF VARIANCE?
#>   
#>   Homogeneity of variance (also called homoscedasticity) is a critical
#>   assumption for t-tests and ANOVA. It means that the variability (spread) of
#>   scores should be roughly the same across all groups being compared. Levene's
#>   test evaluates this assumption.
#>   
#>   HOW LEVENE'S TEST WORKS:
#>   
#>   The null hypothesis states that all groups have equal variances. With a
#>   p-value of 0.0737 (greater than alpha = 0.05), we fail to reject the null
#>   hypothesis. This is good news! It means the variances across your groups are
#>   statistically similar.
#>   
#>   WHAT THIS MEANS FOR YOUR ANALYSIS:
#>   
#>   The spread of scores is similar across all 2 groups. This means you can use
#>   standard statistical procedures (regular t-test or ANOVA) without
#>   modification. If this assumption had been violated, you would need to use
#>   Welch's t-test or Welch's ANOVA, which don't assume equal variances.
#>   
#>   VARIANCE RATIO INTERPRETATION:
#>   
#>   The variance ratio (largest group variance ÷ smallest) is 1.57. Common
#>   guidelines: • Ratio < 2.0: Excellent equality • Ratio 2.0-3.0: Acceptable •
#>   Ratio 3.0-10.0: Consider Welch correction • Ratio > 10.0: Strongly recommend
#>   Welch correction
#>   
#>   Your ratio is excellent (ratio = 1.57 < 2).
#>   
#>   TECHNICAL DETAILS:
#>   
#>   F-statistic: 3.269 with df = (1, 98) Sample size: 100 across 2 groups
#> 
#> 
#> ========================================================================
#> VISUAL DIAGNOSTICS: How to Check Variance Equality with Plots
#> ========================================================================
#> 
#> Visual inspection often reveals variance differences more clearly than
#> statistical tests. Here's how to create and interpret diagnostic plots:
#> 
#> --- BOXPLOT (Best for Comparing Group Spreads) ---
#> 
#> Create the plot:
#>   boxplot(your_data ~ your_groups,
#>           main = "Distribution by groups",
#>           xlab = "groups",
#>           ylab = "Values",
#>           col = c("lightblue", "lightgreen", "lightyellow"))
#> 
#> How to interpret:
#>   • BOX HEIGHT = Interquartile Range (IQR), reflects spread
#>   • Similar box heights = Similar variances ✓
#>   • Very different box heights = Unequal variances
#>   • Whisker length also indicates spread
#> 
#> Rule of thumb:
#>   - If one box is 2-3x taller than another → Possible violation
#>   - If one box is 5x+ taller than another → Clear violation
#> 
#> --- VARIANCE PLOT (Side-by-Side Standard Deviations) ---
#> 
#> Create the plot:
#>   # Calculate group SDs
#>   group_sds <- tapply(your_data, your_groups, sd)
#>   
#>   # Plot
#>   barplot(group_sds,
#>           main = "Standard Deviation by Group",
#>           xlab = "groups",
#>           ylab = "Standard Deviation",
#>           col = "steelblue")
#>   abline(h = mean(group_sds), col = "red", lty = 2)
#> 
#> How to interpret:
#>   • Bars of similar height = Equal variances ✓
#>   • One bar much taller/shorter = Unequal variances
#>   • Red line shows average SD across groups
#> 
#> --- SPREAD-LOCATION PLOT (Advanced) ---
#> 
#> Create the plot:
#>   # Fit a model
#>   model <- lm(your_data ~ your_groups)
#>   
#>   # Plot residuals vs fitted
#>   plot(model, which = 3)  # Scale-Location plot
#> 
#> How to interpret:
#>   • Horizontal red line = Equal variances ✓
#>   • Upward/downward trend = Variances increase/decrease with mean
#>   • Funnel shape = Heteroscedasticity
#> 
#> --- YOUR GROUP STATISTICS ---
#> 
#>   A: SD = 1.97, Var = 3.9, n = 50
#>   B: SD = 1.58, Var = 2.49, n = 50
#> 
#> Variance Ratio: 1.57 (A.var / B.var)
#> 
#> --- PRACTICAL ADVICE ---
#> 
#> • With equal sample sizes: Violations less problematic (tests are 'robust')
#> • With unequal sample sizes: Violations more serious, definitely use Welch
#> • If largest variance goes with smallest n: Most problematic scenario
#> • If largest variance goes with largest n: Less problematic but still use Welch
#> ========================================================================
#>
